A major transformation is happening. Over the past 20 years, more than 700 million people have raised their incomes and escaped poverty. Every year, six million fewer children die from disease. Millions more girls are in school, and millions more people have access to clean water.

Many managers try to stay positive by using a “feedback sandwich.” This means they put a negative comment between two positive ones. But if they do this all the time, workers may think the positive parts are just there to cover up the negative, so the praise stops mattering. Positive feedback shouldn’t be used only to make bad news easier to hear. It should also be given by itself to recognize and encourage good work.

I am part of a group called the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Don’t think about scary movie robots like the Terminator. Think about what is happening now. Armies already use machines, like drones and guard robots, that can hurt or kill people with very little help from humans. The next step could be robots that follow orders but still choose on their own who to kill. I think this is wrong and dangerous for everyone. We need to be very careful about what we let machines do.

More people are learning English than all other languages put together, and English is used in the most countries. But Chinese has the most native speakers by far. There isn’t much connection between how many native speakers a language has and how many people are learning it. However, there is a stronger link between the number of learners and the number of countries where the language is spoken.

Your manager stops you and says she needs to talk about how you did on the recent project. You worry all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong. On Monday morning, you go into her office. She starts by praising your work, and you wonder if this is the start of a “feedback sandwich.” In a feedback sandwich, people say something nice, then bring up the real problem, and then say something nice again.

Born in the USA is a fast, catchy rock album, but its lyrics are still powerful. Behind the upbeat sound are stories about the dark side of the American dream. Many songs show the struggles of hard-working, everyday people and the bitterness and anger they feel when life doesn’t bring riches or fame. For example, Glory Days is about small-town people looking back on their youth, when they felt they could do anything. Downbound Train tells of a young man whose life falls apart after he loses his job. It’s easy to imagine Bruce Springsteen writing about real people he knew—and the life he might have lived if he hadn’t become a star. This album makes it clear that “the Boss” has a rare and powerful talent.

Lewis Pugh wants to increase the share of the world’s oceans that are protected—from about 3% now to 10%—to repair damage caused by people, like overfishing, pollution, and trash. He has seen this damage up close during his trips. He has swum over coral reefs that have turned white (bleached) because the water is warmer. He has also seen empty areas in the shallow Red Sea, with little sea life and plastic scattered around. Pugh believes nature can recover if we give it space, but time is running out. If we don’t start caring for our oceans now, we could soon face a problem we can’t fix.

Best-selling author Terrie Sharp knows how to tell a good story. She has won the Olive Crime Writer Award twice. She was born on a housing estate in Glasgow that had the city’s highest crime rate. There, she learned to keep quiet, stay out of trouble, and even how to open car doors with a knife. Luckily, she used that knowledge only to write her novels. She is not so quiet now. She appears on popular daytime shows like Police Today and speaks at writing conferences across the UK.

Do you think things are getting worse? Is progress impossible? In his book Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at how people are doing and finds good news. Today, many people live longer, healthier, freer, and happier lives. But he also gives a warning. The Enlightenment is the idea that we should use reason and science to make life better. Pinker says these ideas are in danger. Some media and leaders try to turn people against each other with “us versus them” talk. They spread fear, hopelessness, and distrust. If this keeps happening, it can cause lasting harm to important systems, like democracy and countries working together.

In old horror movies, the main characters were often in trouble and couldn’t call for help or the police. Today, cell phones make that harder to believe. So to keep the suspense, movies often take away the phone signal. If you’re the hero in a horror movie, it’s almost guaranteed that when you really need to call, you’ll have no service. Or your battery will die right as you make the call. Sometimes both happen.

In the 1950s, banana companies in Central America were losing their best-selling banana, the Gros Michel, also called Big Mike. Now the same problem is hitting its replacement, the Cavendish. Gros Michel bananas were easy to ship, had thick skins, and tasted sweet, so farmers grew them on most plantations in Central America. United Fruit, the biggest grower and exporter in South America at the time, grew huge numbers of bananas by making new plants from pieces of the stems instead of using seeds, and by planting them very close together in the fields.

Most spiders have venom, which is a kind of poison. They use it to catch their food, not to hurt people. Only about 25 kinds of spiders have venom that can really harm humans. Spider bites can hurt, but they almost never cause death. In Australia, the Sydney funnel-web spider has not caused any deaths since doctors made a special medicine called antivenom in 1981. Also, do not bother hairy spiders like tarantulas. When they feel scared, they can flick tiny, itchy hairs into the air. These hairs can stick in your skin or eyes and make them sting and itch.

This common pattern in horror movies was very popular in the late 1900s. It starts with a group of teenagers having fun, but it ends with everyone dead except one girl. At first, the girl is usually innocent, shy, and not very strong. By the end, she becomes tough and good at solving problems. The “last girl” almost always survives.

If we want to understand where our ability for complex language came from, we should look at how the human brain is different from other animals. It’s not just about brain size. What the brain can do, and when and why those abilities developed, also matter. There are only a few physical clues. Artifacts left by our ancestors don’t show what kinds of speech they could make. But in early human remains, we can study the mouth, throat, and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had the right speech organs to make complex sounds. Before that, scientists can only guess whether early humans used simpler sounds to communicate.

Society, not nature, tells girls to pick art and language arts and leave math and physics to boys. Kids also don’t see many women working in science. In cartoons, movies, and books, the crazy scientist, genius inventor, or brave astronaut is usually a man. People also think scientists are nerdy, not very social, and work alone—but that’s not true. These false ideas in the media can make girls feel that science isn’t for them. Seeing more positive female role models in science would help girls feel confident and like they belong in those subjects.

The Scallion is printed every week and handed out for free in university buildings. About 10,000 students read it. It is written and produced only by students. A survey shows that students and staff value it for entertainment, learning about culture, and gaining work experience. However, printing costs a lot. Also, some students can’t get a copy easily because you have to go to campus to pick one up. There is also an environmental problem: many copies end up as trash on campus.

At Girox Foods, about 12% of our employees leave each year. That might not seem high, but the usual rate in our industry is only 7%. The main goal of this report is to find out what makes employees feel engaged at our company. Based on what we learn, we will give suggestions to make the workplace better and help us keep more employees.

A lot of what the speaker said felt true to me. I think there is a danger: the more connected we are online, the more lonely we can feel. This may not be a big problem for my generation, because we spent many years without today’s technology. We know how to be alone, and we know it is okay to be alone. But people under 20 are a different story. They are so busy messaging and posting that they rarely spend quiet time alone, and they might not learn how to enjoy their own company. Also, they are learning to communicate through texts that can be edited and changed, instead of learning the skill of real, face-to-face conversation with the person right in front of them.

Don’t always add criticism right after praise. If people expect a negative comment every time you say something nice, the praise loses value and they may ignore it. Give praise by itself sometimes. Save helpful feedback for another time.
